> Indeed, interfaces should become immutable once they are published,  
> but
> there are ways to support interfaces with added methods without  
> breaking
> backward compatibility. Here is how.
>
> Suppose you publish an interface:
>
> public interface IAccount {
>   public void processCash();
> }
>
> In v2, you decide your account needs to support credit cards as  
> well, so you
> create the following interface:
>
> public interface IAccount2 extends IAccount {
>   public void processCreditCard();
> }


This path leads to madness.

Every class that you'd like to extend, without modifying, will result  
in a hierarchy.  If these classes are already in a hierarchy then  
you'll have a two dimensional hierarchy, or a ladder.  e.g.

Employee<|--------------Employee2
    A                        A
    |                        |
SalariedEmp<|---------SalariedEmp2
    A                        A
    |                        |
CommissionedEmp<|---CommissionedEmp2

I HOPE that the trick used in COM and Eclipse that you were referring  
to was:

      |IAccount|    |IAccount2|
          A              A
          |              |
          +------+-------+
                 |
              |MyAccount|

(i.e. the Interface Segregation Principle) Which satisfies Elliotte's  
third point since users of IAccount do not need to know about  
IAccount2 unless they want to call processCreditCard.
